description: Rene "Alfred" G developed and released Real Tracker in 1999. Before being discontinued, its primary users were musicians and retro gaming music enthusiasts, who used the program to create and play music with retro sound chips used in older gaming systems like the Commodore 64 and Nintendo Entertainment System (NES).

It supports various audio formats and includes tools for composing, editing, and arranging sound via a visual interface where notes, effects, and instruments are represented in a grid or pattern format. Users may create instrumental tracks and sound effects Real Tracker.
NOTE: Real Tracker users may refer to the instrument data stored in RTI files as "voices."
